titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Harold C. Conklin Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday May 4, 2019 at 07:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers comprise correspondence, maps, and topical files documenting the research of anthropologist Harold C. Conklin and his colleagues, particularly in the area of linguistics and focusing on the Philippines. The papers also represent Conklin's professorial, curatorial, and administrative work at Yale University.

langmaterial.language: The materials are primarily in English, with specific topical files containing Ilocano and Tagalog.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection whether such works are at Yale or physically located elsewhere in the world. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Harold C. Conklin Papers (MS 1956). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Harold C. Conklin Philippine Collection (AFC 2001/007), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold C. Conklin (born 1926) received his B.A. degree from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1950 and his Ph.D. from Yale University in 1955. He taught anthropology at Columbia University from 1954 until 1962, at which time he joined the Yale faculty. Conklin served as chair of the Department of Anthropology, curator of Anthropology, and director of Graduate Studies, as well as director of the Division of Anthropology at the Peabody Museum of Natural History. An emeritus professor, he retired from Yale in 1996. He was also the Frank Muzzy Crosby Professor Emeritus of the Human Environment. Conklin pioneered research in the field of ethnoscience, a discipline dealing with the way in which inhabitants of a particular area understand and treat their environment. His research focused primarily on ecology, ethnology, and linguistics in Southeast Asia, particularly the Philippines, and he authored numerous publications and articles in his field. Conklin died on February 18, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers comprise personal and professional correspondence, maps, and topical files, documenting the research of Conklin and his colleagues, particularly in the area of language in the Philippines. Maps were created in part by the American Geographical Society and the Army Map Service. The Topical Files include professional events and organizations in which Conklin participated; research materials of colleagues Leonard Bloomfield, Frederick Russell Eggan, and Robert B. Fox; and materials relating to the Tasaday Controversy, in which the Tasaday, an indigenous people of Mindanao, a Philippine island, were considered in the 1970s-1980s to be the last vestiges of a stone age culture. Anthropologists and journalists questioned the validity of this claim. Additional files document Conklin's professorial, curatorial, and administrative activities at Yale, particularly in the Department of Anthropology and the Peabody Museum of Natural History.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in three series: I. Correspondence, 1944-2005. II. Maps, 1908-1977. III. Topical Files, 1897-1998.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as it was received from Harold Conklin, in rough chronological order based on meaningful periods in his career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Maps deal primarily with land usage, district drainage, and related topics in the Philippine islands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1977 enlargement of a 1908 Hodgson and Briesmeister map (1 : 2500,000; 1 : 1,115,000).

scopecontent.p: Label: Area I aerial photo coverage, 1 : 50,000, paper underlay of combined AMS (Army Map Service, Corps of Engineers) sheets (hab + 1967), 1972; film overlay - air photo index; ISA/tg 1972, H's negs; PAF photography, 1963-1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 : 50,000 MS and AS sheets: (M-362) overlay, Plate 4; (M-362) Santos, 1969 Apr 16, Plate 4, AP 54; (M-363) color tint elevation band overlay, 1969 Jun 9,Plate 4; (M-364X) Plate 5, District drainage, Ifugao, 1974; Plate 5, 3 small maps of Ifugao districts (1973-1975).

did.unittitle: Pu'itan, Kinnakin, Bayninan (North Central Ifugao), Philippines

langmaterial.language: The materials are primarily in English. Some notecards contain Ilocano and Tagalog with English translations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topical Files include professional events and organizations in which Conklin participated; research materials of colleagues Leonard Bloomfield, Frederick Russell Eggan, and Robert B. Fox; and materials relating to the Tasaday Controversy. (The Tasaday, an indigenous people of Mindanao, a Philippine island, were considered in the 1970s-1980s to be the last vestige of a stone age culture. The validity of this claim was questioned by anthropologists and journalists.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by subject and alphabetically therein.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of 2"x5" note cards, some with Slavic forms on the verso.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes memorial brochure, HCC notes, and information on Eggan's papers.
